**Opening Note**

The constant flow of bad news, lies, and repetitive reporting is turning us all into zombies living under a narcissistic dictator who can’t remember what he said yesterday. National treasures, monuments, and holidays are being torn down and rebuilt in his name. His sycophantic minions are inflicting terror on the immigrants who help build and maintain our economy. In the background, the evil Stephen Miller is said to want Kristi Noem’s ouster because she is not cruel enough, not tough enough, and not making America white enough.

I need some relief.

I was inspired by some of your comments to expand my article **“The Breach”** into a novel. I’ve been working on that.

Starting today, I’m going to serialize the opening chapters here on Substack. Monday, Wednesday, and Saturday, you’ll get a new installment. Tuesday and Thursday will be my regular articles.

It’s fiction, but only barely. And that’s the point.

The science is based on the polar vortex that’s really happening—the reason you’re shoveling snow and freezing this month.

I hope it gives you a way to step out of the noise without losing sight of the stakes. I hope it gives you relief without sedation. And more than anything, I hope it reminds you that even in a collapsing reality, story is one of the last places they can’t rewrite for us.

Please send me comments and suggestions. This is a journey-in-process. Your thoughts will tell me which road to follow.

***

### **THE BREACH**

**Prologue**

In the first week of December 2025, the atmosphere stopped behaving politely.

By now you’ve seen the headlines: the polar vortex fractured early—weeks ahead of any model—and the jet stream buckled like wet steel. The Midwest froze under a sky the color of old nickel. The East Coast took its turn next: sudden hard frosts, breath drifting sideways, thin rime tracing windows from the _inside_. The storm tracks weren’t just erratic; they looked intentional, like someone had dragged a fingertip across the continent and the weather decided to follow.

Nothing supernatural. Nothing mystical.

Just the atmosphere pushed beyond the limits we assumed were stable.

When the vortex weakens this early, the stratosphere folds downward. Wind rings collapse. Temperature layers scrape against each other like sheets of glass. Under the right imbalance, air stops acting like a fluid and starts behaving like something closer to architecture—stacking itself into quiet, rigid geometries normal people mistake for “weird fog.”

Fog that doesn’t drift.

Fog that holds its line.

Fog that behaves as though the world has been given a new set of instructions.

None of this is outside meteorology. You can find the precursors in the literature: boundary-layer inversion, gravity-wave ducting, laminar entrapment. But those events flicker and break. They don’t persist.

This story asks a different question.

What if the structure _holds_?

What if it strengthens?

What if air, water, frost, and pressure begin to answer the same rhythm—quietly, patiently, without announcing themselves?

People would notice first in their bodies: breath that won’t sync, balance slipping without a push, the sense that a room is somehow “breathing wrong.” Animals would sense it earlier. Instruments earlier still. And by the time the sky reveals the pattern outright, it’s already too late to call it an anomaly.

It has become a preference.

This is the breach point—not an explosion, not a catastrophe, but a moment when the world chooses coherence over chaos. A moment when familiar physics rearrange themselves into something uncomfortably close to intention.

Unlikely? Yes.

Impossible? You’re living in the year 2025. After this week’s weather, tell me what still qualifies.

This novel begins at the moment the atmosphere begins to **prefer** a new geometry.

And once a preference forms, the world beneath it must answ

**1 — The First Briefing**

The building flinched before the math did.

It wasn’t a quake in any official sense—just a thin, sideways shiver through the Fisheries and Oceans lab, enough to make Lena Armitage’s spoon tap the inside of her mug and shift the fluorescent hum half a tone higher. She lifted her hands from the keyboard out of instinct, waiting for the familiar follow-on jolt that never came. The vents breathed, pipes ticked in the walls, and Halifax glowed its usual sodium orange behind the midnight windows.

“Well,” she murmured. “That’s not ominous at all.”

She nudged the mug back from the edge and rolled her chair closer to the central workstation. Most of the building had gone dark hours ago, leaving only the soft pools of monitor light across abandoned desks. Someone had left half a muffin beside the printer. A backpack slumped under a chair as though the student intern who owned it had evaporated mid-stride. The cleaning crew had already passed through. The place felt hollow in the way labs often do after midnight—quiet, productive, waiting for someone to acknowledge whatever unsettled the air.

She didn’t like when buildings felt like that. She’d grown up with the granite patience of New Hampshire towns, old mills refitted into research spaces, structures that spoke only when their foundations had something genuine to say. This place felt different tonight. More attentive than settled.

Her simulations still ran on the center console: four overlapping atmospheric grids, each misbehaving in its own particular style. One refused to converge at all. Another produced a clean solution that failed Lena’s intuition test—a surface layer too stable for the season and a boundary wind that reacted as though nudged by a soft, guiding hand.

“Don’t give me that,” she told it. “No one here believes you’re well-behaved.”

She checked the timestamp of the micro-tremor—nothing on the official seismic feed, nothing from Dal or the regional network. Too subtle, too selective, or both. The ridge north of the city sometimes burped a minor event, but those had signatures. They stamped their feet and left data. Whatever she’d felt left nothing at all.

She ran a quick anomaly scan anyway. It returned a quiet, almost respectful blank.

Lena leaned back and pressed her palms over her eyes. She’d been at this station for six days—temporary assignment while the Atlantic Ridge project recalibrated after a series of spring storms, with Maine’s climate lab and UNH’s atmospheric center feeding data into the model. It was the kind of collaboration she loved: stubborn oceanographers, prickly atmospheric physicists, and a few hazard-response analysts like her keeping the peace.

And now, apparently, tremors that didn’t register.

She dropped her hands and stared at the simulation again. Fog bands over the harbour weren’t cooperating with the model outputs—not unusual in itself, fog being notorious for telling physics to mind its own business. But earlier that night, one of the observers on the ridge had radioed in something stranger: horizontal lamination forming too quickly, the layers cleaner than any natural stratification should allow.

She had chalked it up to instrumentation. Fog tricked LIDAR; everybody knew that. But the ridge observer’s voice had carried a tone she recognized from a lifetime around weather people—bewilderment without the courage to name it.

Now her building had shivered.

She pulled up the ridge camera. At first glance, everything looked ordinary: the tree line, the rocky outcrop, the thin conveyor belt of fog spilling from the west. But when she increased contrast, a faint line appeared at the lower edge of the frame—a plane of… something. Water or air or neither, lying too straight across the slope.

Fog didn’t do straight.

Wind didn’t either.

The fluorescent hum shifted again, a subtle change in amplitude that didn’t belong to the electrical panel. She froze and listened. Nothing followed. But the back of her neck prickled.

“Okay. Enough.” She grabbed her jacket. “If the numbers won’t explain themselves, we’ll go bother the ridge.”

She headed for the corridor, pausing beside the break room window. Halifax lay quiet beneath the cloud cover, lights softened by the low ceiling. But over the harbour, the fog wasn’t behaving at all. It wasn’t streaming or curling. It was… aligning. Drawing itself into a loose, shallow arc bending toward the point where the ridge met the shoreline.

The sight tugged at a memory from grad school visualization labs: a solution grid adjusting when an early timestep didn’t match the boundary conditions. The atmosphere didn’t have boundary conditions—not like that.

She descended the back stairs, boots ringing lightly on the metal treads. The stairwell air felt heavier than when she’d arrived earlier in the night, as though the building had been exhaling for hours and had decided now to hold its breath.

Her phone buzzed twice.

Ellison:

You seeing this on the harbour feed?

A second text:

Fog’s acting like it has instructions.

She typed back:

On my way up.

Outside, the loading-bay door clattered behind her. The cold hit first, then the smell—wet, metallic, like rain that hadn’t fallen yet. Fog hung low, thickening in slow shapes that suggested intention more than drift. She drove through it, headlights carving two narrow tunnels in the white.

As she climbed toward the ridge turnout, radio chatter filled her cab. Marissa was tracking unusual conductivity on the upper sensors. Ellison kept asking for confirmation that the lamination wasn’t a camera artifact. And the Portland meteorologist on remote support—Geoff—had stopped couching everything in disclaimers. He sounded like a man staring at a puzzle he sincerely did not want solved.

“Wind vectors disagree with your visuals,” Geoff said. “Either the fog’s inventing new physics or something is imposing geometry.”

Imposing geometry. A phrase fit for a horror novel.

The turnout appeared after the last curve. Lena pulled in beside Ellison’s truck and stepped out into air that resisted movement, as though viscosity had been rewritten without her consent.

Marissa waved from the equipment table. “About time. We’re getting shapes.”

“What kind of shapes?” Lena asked.

“Horizontal layers again,” Marissa said, “but tighter this time. Three distinct bands over the bowl. And something’s pulsing through them.”

Lena walked to the overlook and saw it instantly. The valley below was filled with fog stepping itself into shallow shelves, each one about a meter apart. They didn’t drift. They adjusted—tiny quivers passing through the layers, like a chord resolving.

“Oh hell,” she whispered. “That’s not advection.”

“Say it aloud,” Ellison muttered beside her, “so we can all pretend we didn’t hear it.”

“It’s oscillation,” she said. “Forced.”

“By what?”

She didn’t answer. She didn’t know.

Then something changed. The top shelf dipped toward her—a careful bow, subtle but deliberate. As it lowered, the harmonic rose. A soft tone, barely audible, somewhere between machinery and breath. It vibrated the edge of her jaw.

“Back up,” Ellison said.

But she didn’t. The fog wasn’t trying to touch her. It was evaluating. Its geometry tightened, layering itself into a form her brain struggled to classify—a corridor, maybe, or the early draft of one. A channel of clarified air that wanted to complete itself.

Her phone buzzed again.

Geoff:

Pressure shift just hit Portland station 3 min ago. Yours next. Watch the resonance.

“Resonance?” she murmured. “That’s what this is?”

The harmonic deepened. The shelves quivered in sympathy. The fog brightened at the core—only a fractional degree, but enough to reveal motion within motion: edging, curling, indexing the world like an algorithm searching for a foothold.

She stepped back, finally, and the fog adjusted with her.

That was the moment her fear settled. Not the sharp fear of threat. The colder kind: recognition.

Whatever she was looking at wasn’t chaotic.

It was learning.

Ellison exhaled shakily. “Well. That’s one for the report.”

“No,” Lena said quietly. “This one’s bigger than a report.”

The harmonic pulsed again. The shelves tightened.

The night waited.

And in the space between pulses—just a sliver, just enough for a single thought—she realized the system wasn’t testing the valley.

It was testing _them_.

**2 — First Patients**

Hannah Benoit pushed through the emergency department doors with the same momentum she used stepping off a rolling boat—leaning forward just enough to claim her ground before the building could decide it for her. The air felt wrong the moment she crossed the threshold. Not tainted, not stale. Wrong. A thinness that didn’t match the temperature or the humidity outside, something she felt along the back of her tongue like a quiet miscalculation.

It was nearly midnight, but the ED looked like the middle of flu season: six new walk-ins, three ambulance arrivals, and a waiting room breathing in uneasy unison. The kind of unison she didn’t trust.

She scanned the triage board, then the room. People shifted in their seats as if motion alone might coax better oxygen out of the air. A man in his forties rubbed slow circles into his sternum. A teenage girl kept swallowing, trying to reset something inside her throat. A fisherman from the Southside crew—she recognized the jacket—sat forward with his elbows on his knees, breathing in shallow, irritated bursts.

“Vent issues?” she asked the triage nurse.

“No,” the nurse said. “We checked twice.”

“Air pressure?”

“Normal.”

Hannah let the numbers roll off her. The room didn’t care what the equipment said. It knew itself, and tonight it was telling her something she didn’t like.

She moved through the first bay to check the woman they’d brought in earlier for chest tightness. Mild symptoms. Normal scans. Nothing anyone could name, but the woman’s eyes tracked Hannah with the clarity of someone who felt the wrongness even if she couldn’t define it.

“How’s your breathing now?”

“Off,” the woman said. “Like the air’s been… flattened.”

Flattened. Odd word. Not the strangest she’d heard this year, but close. Hannah nodded and nudged the oxygen flow a notch. Nothing in the body behaved normally when the world itself went crooked.

A monitor chirped in the next bed. Then another. Not alarms—tiny acknowledgments, like the machines clearing their throats in sequence. Hannah turned toward the sound.

The room inhaled.

Subtle, but unmistakable. Every patient drew breath at the same moment. Not a gasp. A coordinated inhale that lifted the hair on her arms.

She stepped into the center of the room, planted her feet, and forced her own breath to stay independent. Years of training had given her that: the ability to keep her rhythm when the tide turned strange.

“Rafi,” she called to the nurse at the desk. “Tell me you’re seeing that.”

He looked up from the vitals screen, brow tightening. “Yeah,” he said slowly. “I’m seeing it.”

Another synchronized inhale moved through the waiting room—fractionally late, like whatever was driving it was calibrating.

Hannah moved fast now, crossing to a boy standing near the radiology hallway. Ten years old, maybe less. His breaths were clipped and uneven, as if he were fighting something the adults were already yielding to.

“Miss?” he whispered. “I can’t keep my breathing steady.”

“You can,” she said gently. “You’re not here to match the room.”

He blinked at her, frightened but listening. Good. Listening was half the work.

She crouched to his level. The building creaked—a long, low sound that wasn’t plumbing or heat, something she’d never heard in these walls. The fluorescent lights hazed at the edges, sliding sideways a hair before snapping back. Even the digital clock hesitated mid-second.

The boy flinched, and so did she.

“All right,” she murmured. “Enough of that.”

She put her hand on his sternum—not pressure, just presence—and guided a slow inhale. His chest rose. The room inhaled a beat later, trying to catch him. She didn’t let him fall into step.

“You breathe with me. No one else.”

He exhaled. She matched him. Two cycles. Three. The rhythm held.

Movement tugged her attention sideways.

One of the older patients—purple windbreaker, clear eyes—had stopped breathing entirely.

Not collapsed. Not unconscious.

Paused.

Hannah stood so fast the chair behind her scraped an inch across the tile.

“Rafi!”

He was already moving. Two more patients had stilled, caught in the same suspended moment. The room’s air pressure dipped, a gentle tightening that made Hannah’s ears pop.

“Don’t you dare,” she said aloud, unsure whether she was addressing the room or the world behind it.

She drew the sharpest breath she could manage—quick, decisive, human—and the pause shattered. Patients inhaled in ragged, mismatched bursts. The vents coughed back to life, as if remembering their job.

The monitors chirped again. Too neatly.

“Okay,” Rafi said, wiping his forehead with the back of his hand. “That wasn’t atmospheric. That was something else.”

Hannah didn’t answer. She crossed to the woman in the windbreaker and checked her vitals. Rising. Breathing again. The woman’s eyes fluttered open.

“What happened?” she whispered.

“The room lost its sense of itself,” Hannah said. “But we didn’t.”

Those words weren’t medical. They came from someplace older—her grandfather’s voice, the one that understood land and weather in ways textbooks couldn’t. She shoved the memory aside and straightened.

The overhead intercom crackled. Feedback whined. Then a clipped voice:

“All staff, report any further anomalies immediately. Convergence indices are rising.”

The word convergence shouldn’t have rung with dread the way it did, but it did. And that meant someone upstairs knew more than they were saying.

Rafi’s eyes met hers. “What does that mean? Convergence of what?”

“Nothing we’re trained for,” she said. “But we’re trained for the people. Get everyone who can walk into the central bay. I want eyes on each of them.”

“And you?”

She looked toward the stairwell.

“I’m going to the roof.”

“The roof?”

“Aye,” she said quietly. “Whatever’s pushing this is sliding over the whole city. If it wants a piece of us, I’m not letting it take the first bite downstairs.”

She didn’t wait for agreement. She crossed the hall and pushed through the stairwell door, climbing fast. Each metal step vibrated underfoot—not shaking, not unstable, but pulsing, as if the building were discovering a rhythm she hadn’t agreed to.

By the time she reached the top, the pressure in her chest had shifted again—not tightness, not fear, something closer to being counted. She shoved the door open.

The sky over St. John’s was breathing.

Fog curled in slow arcs over the harbour, bending in responses she recognized not as weather but as coordination. Along the horizon, light folded in ordered intervals, as if the atmosphere had been drafted with a compass.

Hannah gripped the railing, steadying herself against the vertigo of a world becoming too organized.

“All right then,” she whispered. “If you’re tuning us, you can start by tuning me.”

The sky pulsed once in answer.

And for the second time that night, she felt the land listen back.
